Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: From Risk Aversion to Innovation: Transforming the Concept Selection Process to Maximize Product Success

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to develop a theoretical understanding of the factors that influence the filtering and promotion of creative ideas through the concept selection process. Three research tasks contribute to achieving this objective. First, an understanding of the fundamental relationship between risk aversion and innovation is being developed through experimental investigations with engineering design students and industry professionals. Second, novel methods for assessing concept creativity are being developed and tested for their impact on the promotion of filtering of creative ideas during the concept selection process. Third, substantive and empirical studies are being conducted to validate the utility of concept selection methods for maximizing the potential for innovation through engineering design courses.

If successful, the results of this research will advance the field of engineering design by developing a theoretical framework for research that investigates the relationship between risk, innovation and concept selection. Designers will be provided with the tools necessary to identify and promote creative ideas throughout the design process. These design tools will also allow companies to develop a sustainable innovation capacity. This research will have an immediate impact on undergraduate students by providing them with concept selection tools and a series of web-based modules to be used in project-based design courses. Other activities, including a design training program geared at undergraduate and graduate women in the US and Morocco, and a K-12 EngInn (Engineering Innovators) outreach program, will disseminate the results to the public, engineering industry, and academia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Concept selection is considered one of the most crucial components of the design process because the direction of the final design is largely determined at this stage. Individuals and companies who select high quality and highly innovative concepts during this process increase their likelihood of product success and radical innovation, while those who select poor concepts have larger expenses including redesign costs and production postponement. In other words, for innovation to occur, creative ideas must be identified and selected through the concept selection process. However, creative ideas are often filtered out during this process because of people’s inadvertent bias against creativity, which is attributed to the uncertainty and risk associated with novel concepts.

The goal of this five-year investigation was to develop a theoretical understanding of the factors that influence the filtering and promotion of creative ideas through the concept selection process by exploring the impact of the decision maker and the concept selection tools utilized. Towards this end, studies were conducted with engineering design students and professionals. This research effort built on previous efforts in engineering design, creative cognition, decision-making, management, and many other areas. The intellectual merit and broader impacts of this work resides in six key outcomes.

Individual Attributes and Creative Risk Taking

Experimental investigations with undergraduate engineering students identified a clear link between student risk aversion levels and their willingness to select a creative idea during concept selection task. Several key individual attributes were also identified as key to this relationship including personality attributes, an individual’s Preference for Creativity, and their score on Kirton's Adaptive Innovative index. Research with engineering industry also showed that professionals’ preferences for unique ideas was related to both individual attributes and dimensions of creative climate.

Bias against Creative Ideas

Longitudinal results (8-week) with engineering students showed that students abandon creative ideas early on in the design process, limiting the creativity of their final design. In design industry, we also showed that professionals prefer ideas with high usefulness and low uniqueness which may contribute to the filtering of creative ideas during the design process. We also highlight the potential role of prototyping in fostering appropriate risk taking in the design process as we found that unique concepts were perceived as less risky when presented at higher levels of fidelity through prototyping efforts.

Ownership Bias and Concept Screening

Our results highlight the profound effects of ownership bias in the concept selection process. Specifically, the results in engineering design industry suggest that design professionals exhibit ownership bias for ideas that are perceived to have little to no future value in the design process. In addition, industry professionals showed preferences for self-generated ideas that were of high usefulness and elegance but low in creativity, indicating an impact of creativity on ownership bias. These same findings were found with engineering students, both in the US and in Morocco highlighting the depth and breadth of ownership bias in the engineering design process and its ability to transcend cultures.  These findings provide new evidence on the negative effects of ownership bias on the design process in engineering industry.

Experience and Risk Taking

In engineering industry, we identified a relationship between an employee’s education level and years of experience and their willingness to take risks on creative ideas in their organization. Specifically, our results showed that individuals primarily responsible for the development (Research and Development) and selection (management) of creative ideas tend to be more financially risk averse than individuals in traditional engineering positions. This suggests that these individuals are less likely to take creative risks, putting their companies at risk of failure due to potential significant losses of creative capitol.

Preferences for Creativity Scale

The Preferences for Creativity Scale (PCS) was developed to measure individual attributes associated with risk taking in the engineering design domain. This scale was validated with more than 200 students and was experimentally validated. Specifically, our results how that the PCS risk tolerance and team centrality sub-scales were associated with creative concept selection during engineering design course projects. This suggests that the PCS is measuring engineers willingness to take risks in concept selection. The tool is publicly available http://pcs.engr.psu.edu/.

Tool for Assessing Semantic Creativity

We also explored how our Tool for Assessing Semantic Creativity (TASC) method impacts student innovation capacities by comparing it to existing evaluation methods. We found that there was no explicit difference in similarities between highly ranked ideas and the final design between the concept selection methods. However, the results revealed that the concept selection method used impacted the novelty of the final design outcome. The TASC tool is publicly available at http://tasc.engr.psu.edu.
